Hi James,

On 9/10/07, James Carr <james.r.carr@...> wrote:

>  On 9/=
10/07, you wrote:
>  >
>  >  Just like everything else, use TDD sparingly. =
 I understand you are
>  >  currently doing this as an exercise, so it's he=
althy to take it to
>  >  extremes and do everything by the book in order t=
o learn, but in your
>  >  real work, use your judgment and decide for your=
self when you are
>  >  indeed writing too much code, in which case it's pr=
obably safer to go
>  >  the usual route (get your code to work, then write=
 tests for it).
>  >
>  >  The downside of TDD is that you can end up writi=
ng a lot of tests for
>  >  business code that you quickly throw away and r=
ewrite, so the amount
>  >  of churn can be quite high.
>  >
>
>  I disagre=
e. When I've found something difficult to write test first
>  I've always d=
one a spike, then delete the code and rewrote it test
>  first. I've always=
 found the result to be a lot more cleaner,
>  especially since I wind up c=
leaning up the code anyway when I used to
>  write tests around them.
>
>  =
I'd rather have my business code tested rather than not test it under
>  th=
e assumption it will one day be thrown away. ;)

Well, I never suggested no=
t writing tests, I was just saying that
sometimes, it's okay to write your =
tests once you're done with the
business code.

Here is a scenario I've see=
n happen fairly often:

Write test1
Write code1
Write test2
Write code2

Th=
en a refactoring comes to mind and you realize you don't need code1
and cod=
e2 any more, so you write code3, and suddenly, you find
yourself having to =
refactor (or throw away) both test1 and test2.

I was simply suggesting tha=
t sometimes, the following flow works better:

Write code1
Write code2
<rea=
lize a refactoring is possible>
Refactor code1/code2 into code3
<happy with=
 the result, now we write the test>
Write test3

Net result:  two less test=
s to write.
